title: The Power of Party Pay by Visible
text:
Visible‚Äôs party pay madness
Visible wireless offers $25 off to users who join a party. So a user who signs up to pay $50 for unlimited data can click one button to join a party and only have to pay $25/mo from then on. Why not just offer users $25 to begin with?
It‚Äôs really confusing to me as a user - why not just give me the $25 automatically if it takes nothing to join a group? Because of gamification.


Why it works
I think their strategy is as follows:

They hope some people get brought in on marketing and never remember to activate a party pay. Let‚Äôs say this number is 20-40%. Perhaps these users fund the rest of the discounts.
Joining a party pay group for free is an easy way to make your customers win. I.e., a user gets $25 off for joining. Gimmicky, but I think it works. So a user has an immediate sense of gratification - a great way to build a strong emotional bond. ‚ÄúClick a button to get $25 off in perpetuity? Nice!‚Äù Anyone would agree this feels better than just starting off with $25.
This makes users want to share and tell others. Especially if customers feel they‚Äôve gamed the system. Who today doesn‚Äôt like a hack?

But even if (1) is wrong, and that 95% of people join a party I‚Äôm sure they‚Äôve done the math to consider how many people they need to sign up to make the money work.


The Larger Strategy
Why would Verizon cannibalize their own sales? I switched my wife out of a $70 unlimited plan on Verizon to a $25 plan on visible for the same service. Well some customers will stay with Verizon because of its prestige and the add on benefits. But users who are cutting the cord are going somewhere else, I‚Äôm thinking Verizon wants to stay ahead of the curve. It‚Äôs a race to the bottom, sure. But it doesn‚Äôt hurt to try to win the race.

title: Pomodoro Principles
text:
I‚Äôve been trying a Pomodoro timer in TickTick and it‚Äôs changing how I approach my work day. I‚Äôve been using it for two days so far and here are the differences I notice:

When my mind knows I‚Äôll get a break at 25 minutes, it allows me to focus more.
It‚Äôs easier to say not to slack messages or impulses to open the news if I know I‚Äôll have time for those things later.
A 5 min break is perfect.
If a distraction pops up, I write it down in my journal and tell myself I can follow up during my break.
25 minutes is short. It‚Äôs amazing how time flies.

I used to hate timing myself after working in consulting. I vowed I would never work on the clock ever again. But don‚Äôt the best athletes pace themselves? Any marathon trainer knows how to set a pace and have rest periods. Why wouldn‚Äôt the same principles apply to cognitive work?

title: Increase Focus through Writing Down Everything
text:
The GTD framework preaches something to the effect of ‚Äúget every todo item down and into a system. It may take dozens or hundreds of tasks to get it all out.‚Äù Essentially, if a task is in your mind, it will slow you down. But if you put it down on paper, it will free your mind to think on other things. Also, more ideas will come.
I‚Äôve put perhaps a hundred things down on paper in the last few days. Interestingly, ideas I had forgotten about came back to my mind. I wrote these down.
There got to a point today though where I had so much on my screen I felt overwhelmed. How will I ever sort through all this mess?
Thankfully, most of the things don‚Äôt need to get done and are either ‚Äúeventually‚Äù or ‚Äúsomeday maybe‚Äù tasks, and not ‚Äúasap‚Äù tasks. So just ignore them.
And secondly, I always ‚Äúknow‚Äù what‚Äôs most important. This documentation process doesn‚Äôt change that. It just helps me to get all the distractions out of my head and down on paper.
Spending time organizing all this stuff seems like a potential waste. But what I realize is that it improves my just-in-time recall. If earlier in the day I planned to buy a dish scrubber in the evening, when the evening rolls around that task magically comes back to my mind. So it‚Äôs really just front loading all the decision making and prioritizing. I think our brains are capable of more subconscious processing than we realize.
(Pause entry to buy dish scrubber‚Ä¶) okay, I‚Äôm back.
Another idea that‚Äôs having an effect on me is the 2 min rule. If a task takes less than 2 min, don‚Äôt organize it. Just do it. Powerfully, this mindset helps me to care less about two min tasks. Or, sometimes there‚Äôs a tendency to over exaggerate the stress something will cause. Like buying a scrubber could be a 10 min task if you want to find the perfect one. But if you only allocate yourself 2 min, you realize this is only a $6 decision and I have better things to do with my time.
Lastly, I love being deliberate about tasks by writing down the intended outcome of a task. It‚Äôs very easy as a data scientist to get swallowed up in all the weeds. Or, rather, when your task is to dig up a gem it‚Äôs easy to get distracted by all the weeds that need to be pulled that are in your way. So by being clear about the reason I‚Äôm diving into the data in the first place helps me re-surface less scathed. Data are a dirty business‚Ä¶

Takeaways
The effect of the GTD framework?

Less FOMO. By writing down everything I can see clearly that 1) I don‚Äôt have time for all of it and 2) the stuff I care about pops up.
I don‚Äôt have to worry about what I‚Äôm not doing because I can easily say no to it as I say yes to something better.
I can see broader connections between a litany of things. This helps me prioritize what my subconscious has been telling me by nagging me about X ideas.
If I start working on something not in my list it makes me ask if this thing is fealty worth my time when I know I have a ton of other stuff to do. (Recency bias I spoke about in my other blog post.)

title: How do you want to be remembered?
text:
On the sports fields of high school, I was often asked, ‚ÄúHow do you want to be remembered?‚Äù The energy behind that question is a rallying cry for someone to go out and score some goals and be victorious. Score goals ‚Üí be remembered forever in the annals of high school lore, the thinking goes.
This question misses the point.
In ‚ÄúEgo is the Enemy‚Äù, Ryan Holiday asks the rhetorical question ‚Äúto be or to do‚Äù. The mindset is that either we can focus on doing great work (spending time on action and education), or we can focus on being great (talking too much, dreaming too much). Ironically, greatness follows those who do, not those who say they will do.
So instead of asking ‚Äúhow will others remember me‚Äù, ask ‚Äúwhat will I do for others?‚Äù



Dan Kiefer via Unsplash


On this Christmas season, remember that while Jesus Christ‚Äôs divinity has been debated for centuries, certainly he‚Äôs been remembered. He‚Äôs been remembered because of the actions he took and the kindness he showed.
Christians believe he was the Son of God, one with literal power over death and rose from his own grave. He could calm the seas and turn water to wine. He was the rightful heir to the throne that his Roman captors sat on. He could have easily freed his oppressed nation to rest on his laurels forever.
Yet the recorded miracles we have from him don‚Äôt involve him showing moving mountains or collecting power and gold. The reason he‚Äôs remembered is because His miracles involve him spending time with individuals and in their service. He healed the sick. Caused the blind to see. He alleviated suffering.
May this Christmas be one where you don‚Äôt focus on what others think of you. May it be one where you enjoy following His example of doing good for others, however small.

Whosoever will be great among you, let him be your minister; And whosoever will be chief among you, let him be your servant: Even as the Son of man came not to be ministered unto, but to minister, and to give his life a ransom for many. Matthew 20:26‚Äì28

Merry Christmas.

title: When data collection goes too far
text:
Self Surveillance
I came across this article in Flowing Data and thought it was fascinating.
I‚Äôve been on a productivity kick lately and notice these apps have habit trackers. I‚Äôve tried using them in the past and have realized it gets too much too quickly. But that doesn‚Äôt mean as a data guy that I don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs a cool idea. It just overwhelms me.
We‚Äôll I discovered that me tracking a few habits a day is junior varsity level. Felix‚Äôs blog is how it‚Äôs done to the extreme. Clearly this guy isn‚Äôt worried about Big Tech or Big Government harvesting his personal data. I love the boldness!
This is just 1/20th of the full page screen shot:

The number of slices and views he has is endless. It‚Äôs crazy to see everything he‚Äôs tracking, partly I‚Äôm sure because he has fun with it and the other part because he deep down hopes there‚Äôs something there.
His quote on Flowing Data has stuck with me:

Overall, having spent a significant amount of time building this project, scaling it up to the size it‚Äôs at now, as well as analysing the data, the main conclusion is that it is not worth building your own solution, and investing this much time. When I first started building this project 3 years ago, I expected to learn way more surprising and interesting facts. There were some, and it‚Äôs super interesting to look through those graphs, however retrospectively, it did not justify the hundreds of hours I invested in this project.

This guy probably knows himself in a way that none of us ever will. He can‚Äôt ever lie to himself and say ‚Äúyea, I‚Äôm good at exercising every day‚Äù because he‚Äôs got the data to back it up. But is this the life we want?


Self Surveillance as a Service
SSaaS? Apparently. Exist.io tries to find patterns in your personal data and tell you when your most happy.



Exist.io


When I researched the Apple Watch team a few years back I came to appreciate what they were/are trying to do: correlate heart monitoring with insurance claims data to proactively identify preemptive signs of cardiac arrest and other health issues.
That seems meaningful in theory because information about other people can be correlated with information about me.
But does info about myself correlate with info about myself? Probably. I have cycles. I have common traps and pitfalls like any human walking this earth. Some pitfalls are daily, some are quarterly or seasonal.
But I can also take 5 minutes to ponder reflectively or talk to a close friend and identify those patterns. What‚Äôs more human?
And what‚Äôs more: if you end up changing your behavior then your past can‚Äôt really predict your future. So all of the data becomes moot once it achieves its purpose: true lasting change. Because if you truly change your behavior based on the insights you glean about yourself, those past triggers and anomalies no longer affect you in the way they did. So when you experience a personal step change in life, you‚Äôre a new you. Maybe not. But maybe.
Also, the new generations growing up on smartphones have a unique challenge: their online identities are given to them before they‚Äôre really conscious enough to determine if that‚Äôs what they want to show the world. Parents posting YouTube or TikToks of their kids are cementing for these kids an identity they themselves didn‚Äôt choose. We‚Äôve all gone through phases of deleting Facebook photos from 15 years ago because it doesn‚Äôt reflect our current self image. What‚Äôs to be said of giving people an opportunity to change if everything they‚Äôve ever said or done is recorded somewhere? Twitter. Instagram. TikTok. Facebook. Every post is cementing us in a way.
I think it‚Äôs better to forget yesterday. Because it doesn‚Äôt have to have any bearing on where you‚Äôre going tomorrow. It can if you let it. But your past doesn‚Äôt have to define you.


Takeaways
Would you rather spend hours setting up digital automatic and manual tracking systems just to learn what you could by opening a gratitude journal every day? Sometimes less is more. I don‚Äôt think digital self surveillance is a direction we should go. (Not to mention the moment you do get hacked you‚Äôll deeply regret it.)
Even blogging can be dangerous for your career. Never know what‚Äôs gonna come back to haunt you years later.
So I should be careful what I say here, that is if I ever care to work for a self surveillance company in the future.

title: Semantic Versioning for Data Science Models
text:
If you‚Äôve ever wanted to tag your data science model, you‚Äôve probably wondered how to version it. Which will it be: vx.4.1, v34.1231.51.21, or v91.x4.dev34? After reading about semantic versioning, I propose a method for versioning data science models.
_________________________  For coaching on data analytics or machine learning, reach out.

title: Semantic Versioning for Data Science Models
text:
An Example
I build data science models by building python packages and committing the code to GitHub. The python package contains all of the support files and a main.py file to run the pipeline from start to finish. The support files could contain either helpful loggers to tell me where the pipeline is breaking down, diagnostic tools such as an AUC-ROC plot, files to engineer features, or files to train different model types. So there are really these three things that could happen to my code at any time. It doesn‚Äôt matter where those changes occur, or how many lines of code changed. What matters is what‚Äôs happened to the model. Each time I get a pull request approved, I‚Äôll update the version number in my repo.

Changing BETWEEN
Increment the BETWEEN version for the following changes:

When the structure of your data changes
If your target variable changes (how you coded it, or data that produced the target changed)
The underlying population you‚Äôre training on changes

Assume I discovered that I had a bad join. The join change might have been a minor one, but it‚Äôs now difficult to really compare the two models because my target was affected as a result. What I was predicting, even if slightly different, is now something different. If you ever feel like you‚Äôre comparing apples to oranges when looking at an AUC-ROC curve, update the BETWEEN version.
With each BETWEEN change, there should be a clear communication in the release notes of why the model is inherently different from prior models. These changes should be less frequent.


Changing WITHIN
Increment the WITHIN number when the following happens:

Features are added
Data sources are added or updated. (You might have several data sources today that help contribute to the target. But adding a data source might just mean adding new features. If you add data in such a way that it changes what you‚Äôre ultimately modeling, update the BETWEEN version.)
New modeling types are added. (You might be using a logistic regression, but add a mo)

So if I added files that allowed me to train different model types, or added files that engineered new features, I‚Äôd incrememnt the WITHIN version. In my mind, this shouldn‚Äôt be a count of features you include, but should just be incremented every time you do something that affects the model performance.
At any time, you might what to view different subsets of features and their effect on the model. So, you might not change the number of features, but add some functionality into your pipeline that now produces three different models in each run. I would increment the WITHIN version number in that case.
Remember, the goal of this type of versioning is to show generally what‚Äôs changed in your pipeline.


Changing PROCESS
Increment the PROCESS version when the following happens:

A minor bug is fixed (unless this updates BETWEEN or WITHIN)
Enhance a logger or aspect of the pipeline
Add a diagnostic plot or table

Basically, any time you add something that doesn‚Äôt ultimately affect the performance of the model, you should update the PROCESS version. Your changes might improve the flow of your code and make you a much happier developer, but if it doesn‚Äôt improve the model, then the key priority of your code hasn‚Äôt improved.

title: What is a model?
text: _________________________  For coaching on data analytics or machine learning, reach out.

title: What is a model?
section: I‚Äôm building a model, you know
text:
I‚Äôm building a model, you know
The first time I heard the word ‚Äúmodel‚Äù was from an engineering professor in college. I had no idea what he meant so I asked him. He looked at me like many who have forgotten their own ignorance and just said ‚ÄúSome calculations in excel. You know.‚Äù
No, you don‚Äôt know. But nod your head so you don‚Äôt look like an idiot. ‚ÄúRight, of course.‚Äù
Why this moment was intriguing to me is one of my personal mysteries. But it was one of those odd moments that stuck. I‚Äôm now here to help my old self make sense of the world.

title: What is a model?
section: The Same Name for Different Things
text:
The Same Name for Different Things
When I told my mom I build models for a living she shook her head. Turns out my dad had been telling her for years that he builds financial models, yet she never figured out exactly what it was that he did.
Let‚Äôs be clear on the common ground. A ‚Äúmodel‚Äù per the dictionary is ‚Äúsimplified description, especially a mathematical one, of a system or process, to assist calculations and predictions.‚Äù By this definition, my dad and I do the same thing. We use numbers to put structure on the world.

title: What is a model?
text:
Types of Models
A financial model is different than a statistical model is different than a physical model or a 3D architecture model. But they all do the same thing: use numbers to put structure on the world.
Every model has a few things in common: - They make assumptions about the world - They use data - They probably make some calculations to help someone make a decision
A financial model might make assumptions in a spreadsheet about how many customers you‚Äôll get per month for the next 12 months. This doesn‚Äôt seem complicated, and it shouldn‚Äôt: models don‚Äôt have to be complicated.
A data science model is one that might try to predict whether a customer is going to click on an ad.

title: What is a model?
text:
How does a model work?
The purpose of a math model is to imitate the ‚Äúdata-generating process‚Äù. Meaning, if you have some data on your customers (what they purchased and when), you would hope that there‚Äôs some rules that your customers are operating under. If you knew their income, their budget, their preferences, etc then you can guess how much they have to spend at a given time. Thus, if you know how much gas is in their tank, the mileage of the vehicle, the MPG of the vehicle, you can predict when they‚Äôll stop to fill up on a road tip. When they fill up, they generate some data. ‚ÄúBob purchased $34.52 of gas on Monday at 5:43pm.‚Äù Why did they purchase at that time of day? And why did they spend exactly $34.52?
If all you have outcome/results data then you can‚Äôt ever make predictions. But if you know what type of car Bob drives, how often he drives, how much gas he had in the morning when he left his house, etc, you can start to predict when he‚Äôll next fill up.
The assumption behind a model is that what was true in the past will remain true in the future.
Why have there been so many issues because of COVID? Nobody could have predicted a world wide pandemic. The world wasn‚Äôt the same. All the models stopped working. Supply chain models. Financial models. Default models. All of these assumptions across all industries started breaking down.

title: What is a model?
section: How do you build a data science model?
text:
How do you build a data science model?
Most people build models every time they calculate the ‚Äúmean‚Äù. This is the most ubiquitous model and anybody can use it. Sum your revenue and divide by number of purchases.
If you want to predict revenue for next Monday, just take the average revenue for every past Monday. That‚Äôs a model.
If Monday is a holiday or the Monday after Black Friday, your model might be very wrong. So you estimate black Friday‚Äôs sales by looking at last year‚Äôs sales. ‚ÄúLast Cyber Monday we sold 2x more than we typically do on a Monday. So I‚Äôll predict that on this upcoming Cyber Monday I‚Äôll do 2x more than what I did in the most recent Monday‚Äù
Now that you‚Äôre taking in some data, your building a model. You‚Äôre translating a theory on how the world works into numbers. You‚Äôre taking last year‚Äôs sales and using it to predict tomorrow‚Äôs sales.

title: What is a model?
text:
Start Simple
Whenever I build models, I always try to start simple and see if something more complicated can beat it.

Use averages
Build a rules-based model
Build a regression model/machine learning model
Build a ML model with rules on top of it

If I‚Äôm trying to predict whether a user will click an ad, the simplest model is ‚Äúwhat % of all users clicked this ad in the past?‚Äù If 20% of all users who see an ad click on it, then my ‚Äúmodel‚Äù is ‚Äúpredict a 20% chance of click‚Äù.
Then to make it more complicated, you can segment your users. ‚Äú10% of men click on this but 25% of women do.‚Äù You now have more data and better predictions.
A ‚Äúdecision tree‚Äù is a machine learning algorithm that just finds those segments in your data. ‚ÄúIf man age 30 in Chicago then 22.3% chance of clicking based on all past behavior of all 30-year old men in Chicago‚Äù. It‚Äôs called a decision tree because it will put every user into mutually exclusive groups.
Some ‚Äúbusiness logic‚Äù model might be making predictions around how your business operates. For example, if there‚Äôs a sale you may know that clicks increase.

title: Building a complex R Shiny Dashboard Using ChatGPT
text:
ChatGPT is nothing short of amazing, but I think I‚Äôll still have a job as a data scientist for at least another year or so.
_________________________  For coaching on data analytics or machine learning, reach out.

title: Building a complex R Shiny Dashboard Using ChatGPT
text:
Data Processing
I asked it to create an indicator variable for me so that I could color my dygraphs chart by forecasts vs.¬†historical:

Here was my prompt:

Don‚Äôt use add_series() since you‚Äôre wrong and it‚Äôs not a function in dygraphs. Instead, append the forecasts to the aapl in the stock_subset function and create a new indicator for the forecasted values where 0 is past data and 1 is forecasted data. Then, color the dygraphs chart based on the indicator value. Re-write this script below accordingly.

Look at that code! It knew to filter appl2$ds > max(appl$ds). That‚Äôs exactly how you subset a prophet dataframe (which returns all historical and future forecasts in one dataframe). It knew that appl was the first dataset and appl2 was the derived dataset. It knew that it had to take the max date from appl. This is absolutely amazing, hands down.
aapl2 <- bind_rows(aapl2, forecast_subset)
aapl2$indicator <- ifelse(aapl2$ds > max(aapl$ds), 1, 0)

title: Building a complex R Shiny Dashboard Using ChatGPT
text:
Data inspection
I then got this error:
I'm getting this error: Error in `select()`:
! Can't subset columns that don't exist.
‚úñ Column `date` doesn't exist.
ChatGPT gave me the ring-around. It didn‚Äôt know that the dates were stored as the rownames, but confidently gave me answers like this:

To it‚Äôs credit, it recommended I inspect the data myself:

Once I figured out the problem, I told it that the rownames were dates, and that date wasn‚Äôt a column. It had just the solution for me:

title: Building a complex R Shiny Dashboard Using ChatGPT
text:
Misleading Functions
Twice, it told me that dygraphs had functions that it didn‚Äôt actually have. It even wrote code for me. For example, it recommended this to me:
dygraph(stock_subset(), main = "AAPL Stock Price") %>%
  add_series(data = forecast_subset, col = "red") %>%
  dyRangeSelector()
And it doubled down:

title: Building a complex R Shiny Dashboard Using ChatGPT
text:
Data Conversion
It told me to use the xts package so that dygraphs could read the data in. This was accurate - dygraphs cannot read in tibbles.

But it was misleading me a little bit. Again, I had to look at the data, because the direct code it gave me was missing columns that it assumed it had.

title: Blogging with Quarto, and why I don‚Äôt use Medium anymore
text:
Been here before, eh?
I probably shouldn‚Äôt write this post considering I‚Äôve also written posts ‚Äúblogging with Jekyll‚Äù, ‚ÄúBlogdown‚Äù, and ‚Äúdistill‚Äù before. I‚Äôm flaky, what can I say. I‚Äôve changed my blogging framework 7 times in 5 years (I started with blogger.com and Wordpress before Jekyll, and even used Medium for 25 posts.)
But it‚Äôs not my fault. There are too many static site generators and it seems that Rstudio is as flaky as me. Meaning, they built rmarkdown, created hugodown, blowdown, bookdown, and distill. Hugodown is a lightweight version of blogdown, and I never figured out why it exists. Then there‚Äôs workflowr and so many other great, random products out there.
Why quarto for me? It seems to have all the stuff that distill has, and then some. And given its design and collaboration with Wes McKinney (pandas guy) in building quarto, and given that Wes wrote his latest book with it, I think this will be here to stay for at least 5 years.


Why do I avoid Medium
Why don‚Äôt I blog with Medium? I wrote 25 posts there over 9 months and loved it. It makes writing and publishing incredibly easy, which is why I did it. With distill/blogdown the limiting factor was I‚Äôd have to be at my computer to get a post in. I love writing on my phone - I have over 2000 journal entries with Day One over seven years, several of which are ‚Äúdraft‚Äù posts for a blog that won‚Äôt see the light of day since I don‚Äôt care about them after I‚Äôve written it. I want to be able to blog frequently, a short little blurb to keep up my writing, and medium enabled this.
But 1) I didn‚Äôt get many views (not that I care) and 2) my writing is stuck on their platform (confirmed to me this week as I‚Äôve tried several old, broken tools that attempt to export posts out of medium).
I got 50x the views on my blogdown site just from organic google searching. From reading other people‚Äôs posts about leaving Medium, it‚Äôs seems that most traffic to Medium posts comes from outside of Medium.
So while I‚Äôm certainly not into blogging for the money, I wouldn‚Äôt mind getting the content to people who it can help. And if medium didn‚Äôt enable this, what is its purpose?
So I‚Äôm back and finally decided that I‚Äôm going to own my own platform. Seth Godin wrote a blog about this topic once. Why be on Medium, substack, Facebook, etc or any other up an coming platform? We‚Äôll they‚Äôre all skewed toward the 1% of people who make money on the platform. Everyone else is wasting their time. So might as well own your content. And better to focus on writing than waste time catching up on every platform.
Also, it‚Äôs fun! There‚Äôs a fuzzy feeling to blogging.


Future of quarto?
I‚Äôm speculating here, but Quarto can be used withR Studio, Jupiter or VS Code. The last editor seems excitingly suspicious.
Perhaps R Studio sees the writing on the wall that VS Code is taking over the IDE world and perhaps taking over the long term future of R Studio IDE. I personally don‚Äôt see why anyone would pay for R Studio when VS Code is free and has a better interface. And while R Studio has a few better integrations for R at the moment, it won‚Äôt once enough people see the light for VS Code and turn their contributions there. I‚Äôve been using R on VSCode for two years now and it rivals R Studio in 95% of the feature set, but 100% has better window management.
So Quarto seems like a great opportunity for R Studio to begin monetizing on a publishing platform like R Studio connect. Platforms like Notion and Confluence are great for everyone except data scientists trying to share reproducible research. But a quarto server seems like a great way to finally bring in Python data scientists into the markdown-flavored documentation world. (Man, I personally can‚Äôt use Jupyter/Google colab notebooks when I can use R Markdown!) I‚Äôd heartedly welcome this prospect, though I have no idea what their plans for Quarto really are.
Till next blog post about what blogging tool I‚Äôm going to use‚Ä¶

title: Writing a Tech Resume
text:
TL;DR: Use the ‚ÄúAccomplished [X] as measured by [Y] by doing [Z]‚Äù format.






Writing resume is painstaking, but let me help jumpstart you. My resume below has gotten me dozens of interviews with top tech companies (Apple, Google, Facebook, Amazon, Microsoft, Waymo, LinkedIn, Hopper, etc).
It got me in the door, but let me be clear I didn‚Äôt pass most of those interviews üòù. That‚Äôs the point of the resume: open the door.
Let me help you get in the door.

My template
Here‚Äôs the google doc link to my resume template, also posted below.
https://docs.google.com/document/d/1n8W79UBiWYhMWHeF4sNDtwaWxySRwU3t9isodbUuycI/view
You can copy this template and put in your own content.
I designed and wrote my resume the way I did by following the guidance of these resources:¬†

Blog: Google‚Äôs Accomplished X as measured by Y by doing Z formula
YouTube Video: Google‚Äôs How to write a resume
Blog: Cracking the Coding Interview: how to write a resume



Commentary

It takes some practice, but the XYZ formula is very powerful.
Emboldening words can be helpful to people who have 3 minutes to scan your resume.
I‚Äôve never gotten commentary on how long my resume is or crammed. I‚Äôm guessing people just glance for a few keywords and some decent content and assume the rest of the resume is good.
I‚Äôve had a lot of discussions in phone calls about my Personal Projects sections. Fellow techies all have their own personal projects and they want to know about mine. It sends a signal you‚Äôre intrinsically motivated.
While my resume is long-ish, I try to think: what story does this bullet point tell? What story am I trying to convey?



How can I Help?
I hope this helps! Send me a message at bryanwhitingcoaching@gmail.com if I can help review a resume or give more tips.

title: De-sciencing Data Science and Talking Like a Normal Person
text:
Building a Data Science culture






Note



TL;DR: Always keep it simple and always bring it back to the business need.


A coworker once asked me for advice on how to bring technical rigor into a non-technical culture.


When the Simple Solution Wins
A few years back I wanted to see if I could predict which NBA team would win in their next match. FiveThirtyEight is a blog that does this every day. Could I build a model as good as theirs?
I built a few models and put up a site. Below I have a table of accuracies for each of my models compared to FoveThirtyEight‚Äôs.

What I learned is that Nate Silver‚Äôs FiveThirtyEight three models are only 66% accurate. In 20 hours I got a model as accurate (V02 above) as his using just team level data (win %, recent win streak, etc.) and no player data (injuries, etc.). Also my model was built using data from 2005-2017 to predict 2019 performance. His model was updated daily with recent stats.
But even more glaring is that if I made a prediction on a single feature (Home % > Away %) I could achieve 63.7% accuracy. This feature is a 1 if the home teams win % is greater than the away teams win %, 0 otherwise. Meaning, the home team wins 63.7% of the time their season win % is higher than the away teams season win %.
Was it worth building an XGBoost model with 30 features to get 65.8% accuracy when just a simple calculation is 63.7% accurate? Depends on business context and how valuable that 2% gain is and what the development/engineering cost of deploying a model is. But if I were you I‚Äôd start with the simple model to get it into production to start generating value and then come back later to optimize.
Caveat: it took a lot of work to discover that feature. 90% of the problem was building the data set. So at the end, building a model was pretty simple once I had the data. (This is where cloud AutoML will take over going forward, sorry!.) And I needed the model to see the feature importance (this was the top feature.) This is a valid data science approach: use modeling to discover the patterns. But just because you have a model doesn‚Äôt mean it‚Äôs worth deploying.
Keep it business focused: when building a recommendation system, start with ‚Äúwhat‚Äôs most popular‚Äù. Why would you need K-means or whatever to begin? And can‚Äôt you build your own K-means by creating heuristic filters? For example: if you want to recommend me a shirt based on shirts I‚Äôve searched, you can find all shirts of same color, price, and size and recommend those. Building a model to take into account dimensions, patterns, what others buy, etc is fine but should be a V2.


Mindsets
There‚Äôs a temptation to act like an academic professor and use fancy jargon when working with your coworkers. Even worse, there‚Äôs a temptation to think you‚Äôre smarter than your coworkers because you know this mathy thing that they don‚Äôt. But remember this quote:

When they are learned they think they are wise‚Ä¶1
1¬†2 Nephi 9:28
This pride power struggle is your downfall for two reasons:

It blinds you to thinking your solution is good just because someone else can‚Äôt understand it.
It blinds you from focusing on what matters most: getting the simplest and best solution.

Your coworkers aren‚Äôt your students eating you. They‚Äôre your smart coworkers solving the same problems you are.
A better mindset is that of a professional athlete, like a football player. They might be dumb as bricks at times but they‚Äôre all incredibly smart players. Can you explain your technical solution like a pro football player would?

Bad: ‚ÄúI built an XGBoost classification model that reduces the RMSE by minimizing the Gini coefficient on each node‚Ä¶‚Äù

Better: ‚ÄúI noticed that most users close the app after they reach this page. I tried looking at some reasons why and found a few common behaviors (DISCUSS, get feedback). I think we can predict when this will happen and here‚Äôs a framework to do that.‚Äù

There‚Äôs a temptation to think ‚ÄúI did all this technical work, I should get credit for it!‚Äù My manager once coached me, ‚ÄúYour stakeholders should be amazed by how simple you made it. Not by how complicated the problem is.‚Äù
The best example I know of this is Chris Voss, an FBI negotiator. Listen to his podcasts or YouTubes. He‚Äôs a humble guy and doesn‚Äôt get into the technical stuff. He knows the principles and keeps the explanations simple. He helps you feel smart when you listen to him. He‚Äôs one of the best negotiators in the world and if you were having dinner with him you‚Äôd think he was a normal guy. This is how data scientists should be.


Bugs
There are two types of bugs in data science: Software bugs and data bugs. You‚Äôll spend 80% of your ramp up time on a project setting up your environment, learning the data, trying to understand the primary keys and logging and unique values, etc.






Tip



Nobody cares about how you do any of this (the same way you don‚Äôt care about how cereal ends up in your grocery store), but they do care that you do it because it shows that you‚Äôre thinking about the right things.
They‚Äôll also worry that you‚Äôre spending too much time on the wrong thing, so make sure you believe your actions are solving a business purpose.




Takeaways

Focus on principles, not technical details.
Get the simplest, useful solution into production first to start creating value. Then figure out if it‚Äôs worth optimizing. If your product gets deprecated in 3 months then the fancy model will be wasted time anyway.
Your stakeholders should be amazed by how simple you made it. Not by how complicated the problem is.
If you can‚Äôt explain a trend with a simple bar/line chart, a fancy regression model won‚Äôt do.
Start with the non-technical (basic math) solution. Then see if you can beat the basic math with a fancy model. Evaluate the cost/benefit of the technical solution relative to the dumb version.
when you have a fancy solution, make sure you compare it to the basic solution. Make sure you can beat the solution your teammates come up with. And make sure you carefully lead them from ‚Äútheir‚Äù solution to yours. ‚ÄúAt first I tried X. X was fine. But X didn‚Äôt account for Y. So I built a model M and saw that M out performs X by 10%.‚Äù
Just because you know/use math, doesn‚Äôt mean it‚Äôs right for the business. Data Scientists can easily be myopic because the work we do is challenging and deep in the weeds.
Your boss doesn‚Äôt care about the nature of the bugs, but you should try to bring first principles to the table so she can cover for you. ‚ÄúI keep hitting this bug in the data. Can we ask/work with Infra team to solve this because it eats my time.‚Äù

title: How I use TickTick
text:
I‚Äôve recently read ‚ÄúAtomic Habits‚Äù, ‚ÄúDeep Work‚Äù, ‚ÄúThe Power of Habit‚Äù, ‚ÄúGetting Things Done‚Äù, ‚ÄúEssentialism‚Äù and ‚ÄúEffortless‚Äù. These productivity paradigms influence this post.
Inspired by this Reddit post, I‚Äôve tried thinking how I want apply the principles of GTD and these other paradigms. I think GTD is great for me because it helps me get ideas out of my head and Essentialism is a better pursuit to make sure I‚Äôm not caught up in minutia. I don‚Äôt see them as incongruent, but one as an ideation organization approach and the other as a relentless focus.
Five steps of GTD:

Capture
Clarify
Organize
Review
Engage


Capture
I have an iOS shortcut that lets me quickly add a TickTick task to my inbox. I put this on my Home Screen for instant access and to avoid distraction. I want to capture the idea, not open TickTick and get distracted by other ideas.
Or I use the TickTick today widget and upload it to today directly. Depends on the task and how detailed I want to be.


Clarify
Here‚Äôs the system I use to clarify.
Definitions:

Task: an action item.
Project: an intended outcome with multiple tasks.
Epic: an intended outcome with multiple projects.
Key Result: high level, long term accomplishment. (Increase revenue 10%)
Objective: a squishy, feel-good purpose statement. ‚ÄúDeepen relationships with loved ones.‚Äù

Task grooming process: Groom the inbox every night and identify the intended outcome and next action. Tag the task.

If the task was ‚Äúsend Birthday card‚Äù, that‚Äôs really an intended outcome and is a small project. The tasks are 1) buy card from CVS, 2) put in envelope with stamp, 3) drop in mailbox. These three subtasks need to be understood. But a separate inbox entry may be ‚Äúpay phone bill by sitting down at my computer at 10pm‚Äù. This isn‚Äôt a project. It‚Äôs just a one off thing. But it can still be clarified with details.
Label if it‚Äôs a project or not. Use iOS shortcuts to make this really easy. For example, gg = ‚ÄúüéØ #Project‚Äù
The challenge is if I should have things as projects or as individual tasks. I would say that as much as things can be independent, keep them tasks. Like ‚Äúapply for credit card1‚Äù and ‚Äúapply for credit card 2‚Äù are both personal finance tasks. But they are independent.
A task isn‚Äôt necessarily short and a project isn‚Äôt necessarily long. It‚Äôs just whether this Indy ended outcome has multiple steps or not that might be done over a few days, whereas a task is probably done in one sitting.
It‚Äôs assumed that unless something is a task, it‚Äôs a project.
Every epic has its own name. I nest epics under ‚ÄúWork > #Epic1, #Epic2‚Äù, etc. This helps me organize my work deliverables. I have like 5 epics right now at work that will span several quarters.

Then I may choose to add tags with metadata, which I haven‚Äôt figured out if this is useful yet. But ‚ÄúAtomic Habits‚Äù says the best way to get stuff done is to stack it. So here is my tagging system to help me stack:

Commitment: ASAP, Eventually, Someday Maybe. Will I do this task eventually? Pay a bill - yes. Learn a language - someday maybe.

Duration: 5min, 30min, 1hr, 2hr, 4hr. 9hr (all day)
Location (where to do the task): Home, Desk, Car, Backyard. Most work things are done at my desk. But perhaps some can be done while taking a walk. Most personal things are done around the house or on the couch at night.
Time of Day: ‚Äú1: Pre work‚Äù. ‚Äú2: start of workday. 3: lunchtime, 4: afternoon, 5: after work, 6: nighttime‚Äù
Focus: ‚ÄúDeepwork‚Äù or ‚Äúshallow‚Äù. Deep work should be uninterrupted and be 3 hours long.
Severity: S1: if I don‚Äôt do this nothing will happen. S3: not doing this will have bad consequences or lots of regret. S2 - in between :).
Deadline: I‚Äôm still thinking about this one. To me there‚Äôs a difference between mowing the law which has a linear cost of looking worse each day for not being cut and failing to pay my taxes, which has festeringly worse consequences the longer I put it off (pay a fine, end up in jail, etc.). I guess this is captured implicitly in ‚ÄúASAP‚Äù commitment. But paying my taxes is only a cost (preventing negative outcomes) versus the ASAP of getting my project finished (positive consequences).

None (default): no consequence for never doing this.
Binary: You either make the deadline or never and this opportunity ceases forever.
Rolling: If you miss the deadline there will be another.
Festering: the longer you put this off the worse it becomes, but no deadline.


As I write this, this sounds like overkill‚Ä¶classic me. I sincerely doubt it‚Äôs useful to of all of this. But having the system available will let me use what I need when I need it. If I‚Äôm still using any of this in a month that‚Äôll be a miracle. But I‚Äôm going to start with something in mind and go from there.


Organize

Once clarified, move out of inbox into a list ‚Äúwork‚Äù or ‚Äúpersonal‚Äù.1
Prioritize.
Delegate. (Myself, someone else.)
Assign due dates and times (if not already done)

1¬†Tags and lists are identical except Lists have sections and views (such as Kanban). In a list you can sort by tag and vice versa. But each task can only appear in one list whereas tags are infinite. I noticed that choosing which list something belongs to can be cumbersome if it‚Äôs in a nested list, so I want only high level lists (no folders) and have this be simple. I also have ‚Äúpersonal‚Äù and ‚Äúwork‚Äù tags which have projects within them, so I don‚Äôt really see why I‚Äôd need to duplicate this. On second thought, each task can only belong to one work project so it‚Äôd make sense for this to be my grouping. I suppose I just don‚Äôt want to manage all that. Or, I chose to use tags to manage my projects because I was cheap and I can only have 9 lists on the free version but unlimited tags? Either way this is easy to reorganize later if I choose to switch. Tags it is for now.

Review

Each night I will review the days tasks and re-prioritize as needed.
Pin the one task/project I want to get done that day.

Essentialism says to take the 6 tasks of the day and choose just one. Then identify what else you need to say no to to ensure you have the energy to accomplish that task.

Weekly planning session to review all of this.



Engage

Don‚Äôt work on any tasks in a day/week that weren‚Äôt planned for that day (unless something comes up).



Final Thoughts
A task system should be saving me time, not consuming it. It should be relaxing me and my anxieties, not amplifying them. I‚Äôm going to give this 30 days and see if my stress decreases and productivity increase. If so, I‚Äôll keep using this system.
GTD states that by not writing down all the ideas, you waste energy because things come back to nag you later. But surely energy is wasted by organizing a valueless idea.

title: Models as a Service and the Future of Data Science
text:
Businesses are Launching Like Crazy
There‚Äôs never been a better time to start a business. The Census shows there are over 200,000 new business applications per month more than pre pandemic.

What‚Äôs driving this?
Listening to The Unintended Consequences of Working from Home it dawned on me that there‚Äôs a hyper acceleration of innovation happening.
Consider the rise of AI tools like ChatGPT and StableDiffusion. Chamath Palihapitiya discusses the expansive applications for these services. What was once SaaS will become MaaS (models as a service). There will be models for everything: copy writing, code debugging, converting wireframes into working apps, ad generation, book writing‚Ä¶
While tools like ChatGPT are just in demo mode, it‚Äôs wildly apparent they‚Äôll be an impetus for new ideas and reducing the friction of getting to the answer. For example, as a data scientist if I need boilerplate code to clean some data, I can ask ChatGPT for the 80% solution. I‚Äôm already spending 30% of my day copying code snippets from StackOverflow and making it work for my problem. ChatGPT will just accelerate that process. 10 years from now if Neuralink can read my thoughts I don‚Äôt even need a keyboard to do this‚Ä¶we‚Äôll build things at the speed of thought.
Consider this for writers and marketers. They‚Äôll use ChatGPT to unblock them, generate ideas, and get started. Innovation across the board will accelerate because the kinetic friction to getting started will reduce to zero. You can then spend your time on the editing and refining.


The Best Time to Start a Business
I digress. Why is now the best time to build a software business?

Compute is cheap. Gone are the days of having to build a server to prototype and idea.
Barriers to prototyping are nearly free and scaling with the cloud is nearly infinite. Consider how the Gas App can launch to 100,000 new users per day with just a few developers.
Modeling is now easy. All cloud services have their own AutoML tools to build machine learning models for you.

The center of all of this is scalable data infrastructure and AI.


Future of Data Science
The data scientist of today may still be using sklearn to manually do hyperparameter tuning, but the data scientist of tomorrow will either be exclusively building MaaS B2B products or be the one person in their organization who will leverage all the MaaS tools.
If we can ask ChatGPT for complex answers it learned from the internet, why couldn‚Äôt something similar be trained on your company‚Äôs internal data? If that‚Äôs possible, then why couldn‚Äôt you just have a Q&A session with your internal ChatGPT? Consider the following example:

‚ÄúHey KITT, what are the user segments generating the most revenue on Tuesdays at 5pm?‚Äù (Analytics)
‚ÄúHow many sales do we anticipate from these users next Tuesday?‚Äù (Machine Learning)
‚ÄúWhat ads have been most effective for us in driving new sales in the past 7 days?‚Äù (Statistics)
‚ÄúOkay, KITT, generate 3 variants of that ad for next Tuesday‚Äù (StableDiffusion generating a new Ad)
‚ÄúI like ads A, B and C. launch an experiment on Facebook/TikTok, run it for three days and dynamically allocate ad spend to the best ad.‚Äù (Business integrations, statistics, ML models)

The data scientist of the future will be the one with deep understanding of these tools and an awareness of their biases. It will be very difficult to know when they‚Äôre lying to you. The in-house data scientist will be keen on knowing the biases in the data fed into these algorithms and how to make judgments on where to go next.
Early stage companies won‚Äôt need data scientists because most of this stuff will be off the shelf and easy for an engineer to integrate. That means that the data scientists will join these MaaS companies to build out optimized products that solve these niche problems.


Takeaways
Data Scientists shouldn‚Äôt be scared their jobs will disappear. They should be excited that they‚Äôll be joining companies that automate what they‚Äôre currently doing and offer it as a service.

title: Getting Things Done
text:
Principles and Core Insights
After 21% my takeaways are:

‚ÄúMy mind is weighed down by all of the ideas of things I can do.‚Äù I waste my time on todos that are just ‚Äúgo to doctor‚Äù, but should be ‚Äúschedule appointment to go to doctor‚Äù. Anything that only takes 2 min should be done immediately. Anything longer later. But I love that clarity - I‚Äôve often written lots of todos but not from the ‚Äúnext action to take‚Äù perspective.
‚ÄúVisions can be built from the ground up rather than just top down.‚Äù I‚Äôve tried writing down big visions for my 10 year future and it never works for me. I‚Äôve got anxiety when I try to think where I want to be in 10 years. I mean, I know I want to be happy, be best friends with my wife and kids and have meaningful relationships but whether I‚Äôm still a data scientist or a farmer by then is anyones guess. (I wanna keep my options open.) But as I look at the things on my todo list and ‚Äúeventual‚Äù to do list, a different picture emerges. I know I want to be a writer (hence this blog), I know I want to travel to XYZ location, to be involved in giving back, etc. TLDR: I know things I want to experience in life. I don‚Äôt have to craft value statements and invent ideas of what to do (seems forced). Instead I can reflect on what‚Äôs currently exciting and important to me and categorize those things into high levels values/missions. This will help me when I need to prioritize so not every whim of an idea gets my attention.
GTD book just lays out what a todo is. It breaks down the problem of doing things (big and small) into what they are (time sensitive, someday, etc). Whether I‚Äôll follow the system is up for debate, but I love the ideas so far. It very much fits my naturally organized mind, but may not work for more spontaneous folks that don‚Äôt like as much structure and list keeping.
Most of my ‚Äútodos‚Äù have been ‚Äúintended outcomes‚Äù, but not ‚Äúnext actions‚Äù. For example, I see I have ‚Äúchange car battery‚Äù on my list right now and ‚Äúplan yosemite trip‚Äù. But these aren‚Äôt todos. I can‚Äôt organize and prioritize outcomes. I can only organize and prioritize actions, he says. Changing these to ‚Äúcall mechanic to book oil and battery change and identify an hour in your calendar‚Äù. And ‚Äúopen recreation.gov when walking around the house and find a campsite.‚Äù
Organize tasks around where you‚Äôll do them. This is in line with Atomic habits which states to be hyper specific about where and when you‚Äôll do something. ‚ÄúCall grandma when I get into my car tomorrow morning to go to work.‚Äù Or ‚Äútake a moment at my desk during lunchtime to find a mechanic by opening Google Maps and plan an oil change. Find 1 open hour on the calendar.‚Äù



Putting it into practice
I‚Äôve been using TickTick for my task manager, which has Lists (folders) where I can put my tasks and tags so I can label and categorize each task. Here‚Äôs my organization strategy:

When jotting ideas write intended outcome and next action as my todo.
Tag with where I‚Äôll do it and provide day or time it‚Äôs due (if applicable)

Move each item to a respective list:

ASAP - there‚Äôs a useful urgency to this task (begin memo)
Eventually - there‚Äôs no urgency but I know I‚Äôll want to do this
Someday maybe - no urgency and no commitment, but it‚Äôs an idea of something I want to do.

Tagging system: tag each item with either Work or Personal. Then within that, some meaningful themes:

ProjectName (work deliverable or personal project like ‚ÄúImproveMyHealth‚Äù, ‚ÄúBuildApp‚Äù)1
Location (where I‚Äôll do it). Around the house. At desk. In car. While cleaning the house, etc. this is habit stacking. Most work stuff is done at my desk.
when I‚Äôll do it. Stack with other activities. Examples: Before lunch.
Duration (how long it takes: 1, 2, 4 hours, 5, 30min). This might be useful for planning.

List system. Move from inbox to list when properly categorized. I like ‚ÄúWork‚Äù and ‚ÄúPersonal‚Äù lists. I think since you can use unlimited tags, and tags can be nested in TickTick, there‚Äôs no substantive differ ne between list and tag. Not sure yet how to use the TickTick lists when tags are so useful. Lists of work and personal.

1¬†Deciding Vision: As I write this, choosing a project might be a good place to insert a goal (intended outcome) as a project name. Instead of Exercise, the intended outcome is improving health. The goal is being able to run a 5k. So perhaps goal/objective is ‚ÄúImproveHealth‚Äù and KR is ‚Äúrun 5k‚Äù. These goals can be identified by asking the 5 whys. If I have an idea if ‚Äúgo running‚Äù as my task, a good grounds-up vision exercise would be to ask ‚Äúwhy do I want to run a mile tomorrow? Is it to accomplish something or to relax my mind? Why is relaxing my mind important to me? Why is my mental health important? Etc. I think subconsciously ideas come of what to do next all the time ‚ÄúI should work out‚Äù but rarely do I take the time to ask ‚Äúwhy do I see the need to work out? What‚Äôs the greater vision here for this task?‚Äù Understanding that vision can help prioritize and build a desire to accomplish the task. If the idea ‚Äúlearn a new language‚Äù comes up, asking why can help me realize ‚Äúoh, this is just for fun and won‚Äôt be for anything meatier than having fun! No pressure on this task and maybe I‚Äôll never do it.‚Äù The nag to run a mile might help me realize ‚ÄúI need to take care of my health, and this can‚Äôt wait.‚ÄùIn summary:

Idea/task comes.
Document in inbox.
Clarify the intended outcome and the next action.
Organize: tag. Set up reminder. Move out of inbox to list.
Review and Prioritize: understand where these ideas will take you and choose your adventure.
Do!

title: Scientific Freedom
text:
Max Plank, GPT 4



‚ÄúScientific Freedom‚Äù






TL;DR: a scientist isn‚Äôt a title, but a philosophy






Scientists are hampered by the peer review process. The notion that some tolerate the process so they can get their grants approved and get tenure, and others eventually accept the process because that‚Äôs how they got tenure, is a sad outcome of human incentives.
Interestingly, inventions have always happened regardless of peer review. Edison didn‚Äôt need someone to review his invention to tell him whether or not it‚Äôs a valid invention. Either the light bulb illuminates or it doesn‚Äôt.
Yet that‚Äôs exactly how things go now. So what‚Äôs the result?
People write to please the peer reviewer. Social conformity. Group think.
People are incentivized to game the system: write a grant that gets them funding so they can get tenure and support their families.
The incentive to be innovative is small, though intellectual curiosity powers through for some. The incentive to stay in line and do what‚Äôs necessary to get approved is strong.
We‚Äôve also learned as a consequence of 2020-2022 that a lot of scientists can indeed be wrong. Today science is becoming less about discovering truth and more about people owning their truth‚Ä¶people love their politics.
What makes a scientist anyway? Am I a scientist because I‚Äôm a data scientist? Because I studied statistics? I‚Äôve never published an academic article in a journal, so is that the threshold?
I think someone who pursues truth through repeatable experimentation is a scientist. Back in Plato‚Äôs day they were just called philosophers.


Today‚Äôs incentives
There‚Äôs a reason really smart people now work at Apple to invent the iPhone, Facebook to work on LLMs, and SpaceX to build rockets. The freedom they feel at these companies is empowering. Per ‚ÄúScientific Freedom‚Äù, if the trends continue then people like Max Plank would never have been able to get the funding needed to invent what he did. Where‚Äôs the money? Social media. Advertising. And now, AI.
People will always be inventive. But it‚Äôs by removing the social barriers that they become so.

title: The Author‚Äôs Angle Matters
text:
Imagine the following story:

‚ÄúIn recent events, a ferocious fox savagely attacked a Turkey, who fortunately was able to escape to safety by pecking out the fox‚Äôs eyes.‚Äù

Simple story. A bit gruesome. But, what in today‚Äôs news cycle is positive? How can we be better readers of the news when it‚Äôs targeted at making us angry?
Foxes and turkeys are highlighted in the news all the time and it‚Äôs often the worst of humanity. The goal of many authors is to evict emotion from you so you‚Äôll keep reading. Anger. Fear. Worry. Those keep you hooked.
What‚Äôs the author‚Äôs motive? Often we have to guess it. Wouldn‚Äôt it be nice instead if authors were transparent about why they were writing a story:

Author 1: I‚Äôm a Turkey conservationist with a passion for protecting turkeys from the rampant fox problem we have. Growing up, a Turkey saved my life when I was drowning in a lake.
Author 2: I‚Äôm a narcissist who hates foxes because one time they ate my cat. I really just need therapy, but I can‚Äôt fathom talking to anyone about my problems. I want you to be as angry as I am.
Author 3: I‚Äôm here to get promoted and if my boss sees that I have a 10% increase in viewership then our company‚Äôs bottom line increases. Im an opportunist who will say anything and take any side that will maximize company profits. How do these three perspectives change the storyline?

Wouldn‚Äôt it be great if we could know the author in addition to what the author is writing about? Every article should have not just ‚Äúabout the author‚Äù but, ‚Äúthree people‚Äôs perspectives about the author‚Äôs intent in writing this that know the author well.‚Äù Of course, you‚Äôd need to verify the three verifiers, but it‚Äôd be a start

title: Starting with Jekyll
text:
Hello world.
I wanted to start a blog. I wanted to set it up for free, use a custom URL (and not something.bloggingplatform.com), and be able to both blog and create tutorials. I didn‚Äôt mind it possibly being technical1. Enter Jekyll.
1¬†Specifically, I was interested in being able to use the command line for my posts. Additionally, I didn‚Äôt mind seeing or using a little bit of code.If you want to get your blog in 10 minutes, skip to below.

Why Blog with Jekyll?
Here‚Äôs why you can and should blog with Jekyll (if you‚Äôre a data scientist):

Jekyll has beautiful, free, open-source templates.
GitHub will host your website for free2.
Jekyll is static.
Jekyll can be simple to set up3.
I tried Wordpress and blogger.com and got frustrated.
The blogging content you create is very portable (easy to take your posts from one blog site to another).
Creating blogs in Markdown syntax is a dream (even for non-technical folks).
You can manage your blog from your terminal
You can manage your blog from your phone (if you have a GitHub-editing app)

2¬†Someone has to host it (i.e., store and display all the files). I started off trying to set up a WordPress blog, but you have to pay another company to host. I didn‚Äôt want to bother.3¬†If you try to set it up by following the instructions on jekyllrb.com, that‚Äôs the complicated way. That‚Äôs how I originally started, got lost for five hours, and stopped. Six months later, I found a better way.But if you don‚Äôt like debugging occasional errors, you probably shouldn‚Äôt blog with Jekyll.
What is Jekyll, you ask? Jekyll is an open-source blogging platform. Anyone can write a template and post it, and anyone else can use that template. Perusing Jekyllthemes.org, you can pick out any template you‚Äôd like.


How did I get started with Jekyll?
As a blogging noob, I‚Äôve discovered there are hundreds of ways to generate a blog (e.g., WordPress, Squarespace, blogger.com, Weebly, etc.). But when my colleague Arthur Lui showed me his blog, I wanted something similar. I first tried Wordpress, then tried blogspot, then gave up and followed Arthur‚Äôs example and landed with Jekyll.


Set up a blog in 10 minutes!
I followed this Jekyll tutorial to set up my first blog. I‚Äôll simplify those steps here to get you up and running quickly:

Get a GitHub account. (2 min)
Go to Jekyllthemes.org. All of these blog themes are free. Find one you like, and Fork the repo (i.e., ‚Äúrepository‚Äù). (2-60 min, depending on how long you peruse)
In GitHub, rename the newly-forked repo from ‚ÄúREPO name‚Äù to ‚Äúyourgithubusername.github.io‚Äù. (1 min)
Now go to ‚Äúgithubusername.github.io‚Äù. Voila, you have a blog.

And if you want to start writing posts, go to your ‚Äú_posts‚Äù folder. Then create new files and follow the default templates that the repository provides. (The blogs will need to be written in Markdown syntax.)
That was my 10 minute promise. If you feel a bit cheated or lost, go to the well-done tutorial and do all the steps. But the steps I listed are the essential steps to setting up a blog from scratch. So if you want to make a few blogs really quickly, after you figure out the first one the others follow nicely. For example, once I finished the tutorial, I followed those steps above to try two other themes before deciding on the Centrarium theme.
To get Centrarium to work, I did have to change some configurations in the ‚Äú_config.yml‚Äù, so there can be some minor debugging depending on the theme you choose. But with a little patience and some Googling, you‚Äôll get it.


Add to Jekyll a custom URL from GoDaddy
You‚Äôll notice I have a custom URL and not ‚Äúbryanwhiting.github.io‚Äù. I used GoDaddy to get a domain. (I have no affiliation with GoDaddy.) Here‚Äôs how I linked GoDaddy with my GitHub Jekyll blog:

Get a domain.
In your Github repo, change (or create) a CNAME file in the main directory. (See my CNAME file for an example). And for the CNAME file contents, just type in the new ‚Äúwww‚Äù that you registered through GoDaddy.
Then, on GoDaddy, go to the section ‚ÄúDNS Management‚Äù. Here‚Äôs where you tell GoDaddy how to connect your newly purchased ‚Äúwww‚Äù with GitHub. Create the following connections:
[Type, Name, Value, TTL] = [A, @, 192.30.252.153, 600 seconds]
[Type, Name, Value, TTL] = [A, @, 192.30.252.154, 600 seconds]
[Type, Name, Value, TTL] = [CNAME, ftp, yourgithubusername.github.io, 600 seconds]
[Type, Name, Value, TTL] = [CNAME, www, yourgithubusername.github.io, 600 seconds]

If you have the CNAME file in your GitHub folder, GitHub and GoDaddy will talk and after a few minutes your custom ‚Äúwww‚Äù will work. You don‚Äôt technically need the two [A] steps, but those connections allow users to type ‚Äúbryanwhiting.com‚Äù instead of ‚Äúwww.bryanwhiting.com‚Äù. It can take up to 24 hours before these [A] connections enable, so don‚Äôt be worried if the short URL doesn‚Äôt work first try. But the full URL should work soon enough.

Here‚Äôs a tip I read today on how to be productive with unstructured time: put your to-do list directly into a calendar.
That way, you‚Äôll always have time for the important things. Remove the things that take up your time and aren‚Äôt as important. I like it.

title: New ideas are distractingly exciting
text:
When a new idea comes to my mind, I want to act on it right away. Perhaps it‚Äôs an exciting analysis idea, a new business strategy I want to scope out, or a question to ask a team member.
But as I look back at my backlog of things to work on, all of these ideas were also equally exciting.
Why is it that new ideas have more weight than old ideas?
They say that effectiveness is working quickly on tasks. Efficiency is knowing what to work on. Discipline is the ability to overcome the excitement of a new idea and place it in proper context of all ideas. Sanity is actively saying no to many ideas so you don‚Äôt get inundated.
Perhaps a good strategy is to have a ‚Äúgut check‚Äù for ideas. If they don‚Äôt pass the highest threshold then let them go.
Process:

What‚Äôs the new idea?
What‚Äôs the potential impact? What would I do with the output of this idea?
How feasible is it?

Step 3 is tricky because I don‚Äôt want a good idea to go to waste just because it‚Äôs hard. Judgment is weighing the trade off between impact and feasibility.
I like Google Forms for logging ideas. It‚Äôs easy to save a Google Form URL to the home screen of my iPhone to make logging new ideas easy. Grooming those ideas is important. Letting go of old ideas is essential. If only I could do the essential‚Ä¶

title: Resume Substance over Style
text:
Earlier in my career I got feedback from a prospective recruiter telling me my resume was ‚Äúvisually imbalanced‚Äù. Of course, the recruiter wanted my business.
But I went on to get over 70 interviews with that same template. I got a job at FAANG and a top startup using that resume template. I haven‚Äôt changed it.

Takeaway
How you write your resume and what‚Äôs on it will take you farther than how you design it.

title: The DataViz battle: Plotly vs ggplot2
text:
R users fall in love with ggplot2, the growing standard for data visualization in R. The ability to quickly vizualize trends, and customize just about anything you‚Äôd want, make it a powerful tool. Yet this week, I made a discovery that may reduce how much I used ggplot2. Enter plot_ly().
For this post, I assume that you have a working knowledge of the dplyr (or magrittr) and ggplot2 packages. I caveat that this post is backed with only 4-5 hours using plotly(), so some statements here may not be fully vetted.
Plotly and ggplot2 are inherently for different purposes. plotly allows you to quickly create beautiful, reactive D3 plots that are particularly powerful in websites and dashboards. You can hover your mouse over the plots and see the data values, zoom in and out of specific regions, and capture stills. Here‚Äôs a basic histogram:

set.seed(1)
library(plotly)
plot_ly(x = ~ rnorm(1000), type = "histogram")





After a brief dabble this week in plotly, I realized quickly the many advantages that plotly has over ggplot2.
Several initial impressions:

Plotly handles multiple wide data columns. I always find it annoying that to color different series in ggplot2, your data had to be in long format. Granted, it takes one simple melt() command to get the data into wide format.
Plotly also handles long format (see below).
Customizing the layout (plot borders, y axis) is easier.
Customizing the legend is easier (in ggplot2 I‚Äôve wanted to remove just one series, which isn‚Äôt always easy).
Documentation is better in Plotly.
Plotly syntax is very intuitive (learning how aes() in ggplot2 works is tricky at first)
Plotly also works for Python, Matlab, and Excel, among other languages.
It‚Äôs very easy to add new series and customize them (one line, one scatter, and one bar, for example)
You can use other fonts (which is possible in ggplot2, but I‚Äôve never gotten to work on my Windows machine)
You can toggle series on and off by clicking the series name in the legend

Benefits of ggplot2 over plotly:

Facet wrapping is very easy in ggplot2. (I think you have to do subplots in plotly.)
ggplot2 is probably quicker for exploratory analysis.


Converting ggplot2 into plotly
An additional benefit of plotly is that you can convert your ggplot() graphs into a plotly object.

library(ggplot2)
p <- qplot(x = rnorm(1000), geom = "histogram")
p








Then, invoking the ggplotly(p) command, we see the transformation:

ggplotly(p)





A draw back of ggplotly() is that if you do refined customization (like putting your legend on the bottom of the graph), ggplotly() doesn‚Äôt seem to pick this up by default.

# ggplot with legend on the bottom
p <- qplot(
  data = iris,
  x = Sepal.Width,
  y = Sepal.Length,
  geom = "point",
  color = Species
) +
  theme(legend.position = "bottom")
p







# Plotly doesn't pick up the legend change
ggplotly(p)





But since Plotly also saves to an object, you can use the %>% notation to pipe and add additional plotting commands. This is similar to the + operator in ggplot().

p <- qplot(
  data = iris,
  x = Sepal.Width,
  y = Sepal.Length,
  geom = "point",
  color = Species
) +
  theme(legend.position = "bottom")
p2 <- ggplotly(p)
# Use the plotly layout() command for legend customization
p2 %>% layout(legend = list(orientation = "h"))





The legend doesn‚Äôt do exactly what we want, but you can manipulate the legend location manually using x and y coordinates. The orientation = 'h' setting in the docs puts the legend on the bottom for default plot_ly() objects. Graphing the same series, we see the legend at the bottom:

plot_ly(iris,
  x = ~Sepal.Width,
  y = ~Sepal.Length,
  type = "scatter",
  mode = "markers",
  color = ~Species
) %>%
  layout(legend = list(orientation = "h"))





(You notice the Plotly X-axis title can get cut off1, so let‚Äôs put that +1 to ggplot2.)
1¬†This may depend on your screen.Plotly seems very intuitive relative to ggplot2 in doing layout customization. Things that took me many iterations on StackOverflow to figure out, like adding a black line on y = 0, are built in to Plotly.

p <- plot_ly(iris,
  x = ~Sepal.Width,
  y = ~Sepal.Length,
  type = "scatter",
  mode = "markers",
  color = ~Species
)
# Put legend on bottom, change the x-axis range, and turn on the x-axis line. 
# Also, make the zeroline visible, and turn it red.
p <- p %>% layout(
  legend = list(orientation = "h"),
  xaxis = list(
    zeroline = T, # Turns x = 0 on
    zerolinecolor = "red", # colors x = 0 red
    showline = T, # Shows xaxis border line
    range = c(-2, 7)
  )
)
# Or, save parameters into a list. Use new fonts (a huge plus)
f1 <- list(
  family = "Arial, sans-serif",
  size = 18,
  color = "lightgrey"
)
yax <- list(
  title = "Sepal length",
  titlefont = f1
)
p %>% layout(yaxis = yax)





Things I‚Äôd like to further explore:

You can export static plotly images out to file. My hypothesis is that Plotly images take longer to generate than ggplot2. So if I‚Äôm mass producing 30,000 plots (which I had to do last month), which is the faster approach? I would assume ggplot2.



Plotly in RShiny Dashboards
The goal in learning Plotly was for me was to eliminate the Excel-VBA dashboard I created using for my manager. Excel has (some) benefits over ggplot2 static charts: you can easily hover your mouse over a series to see the data value, and most industry users know how to manage an Excel axes. Grated, you can build in an RShiny widget to allow the user to control the axes, but Excel comes with that knowledge base built-in. ggvis allows for the powerful library of Google charts, but I think for a reactive dashboard, plotly is a great way to go2.
2¬†Of course, this is relative to the chart you‚Äôre trying to make.So Plotly solved the Excel problem for me. Now my manager can click and zoom to the parts of the graph that are interesting, and hover the mouse to see the values. Just use renderPlotly() instead of renderPlot() in the server.R file, and plotlyOutput() instead of plotOutput() in the ui.R file.
More info here: RShiny and Plotly


RShiny vs Plotly Dashboards
Both RShiny and Plotly allow for creating dashboards. Plotly allows you to build dashboards as well. If you‚Äôre just interested in only visualizing charts and trends, Plotly dashboards seem like the way to go. But to build reactivity into your dashboard (like subsetting your sample, changing date ranges, etc.), RShiny still seems like the more customizable solution.


Final thoughts
Overall, it seems that ggplot2 is quicker to build and find what you want. With facet wrapping, the qplot() command, and ggsave(), you can whip something up fast. Plotly is better for dashboards, as you can interact with the plots. I feel like Plotly has a better syntax and documentation, and so it may be easier to get a basic plot to look how you want it to. But ggplot2 seems to have more advanced features, so if you want to get into refined customization, you may want to stick with ggplot2. They‚Äôre both great, and serve different purposes, but I‚Äôll be using plotly for my RMarkdown and RShiny visualizations going forward.

title: Data Beats Opinions
text:
When I co-started a company several years ago, my founders and I would canvass neighborhoods knocking doors. We‚Äôd discuss our ideas for a new product one door at a time. After each conversation, the product took a new form. Eventually, the product took shape and we had a successful kickstarter launch.
Since that time, I‚Äôve thought about how valuable it was to get information straight from the source.
Alberto Savoia‚Äôs new book, ‚ÄúThe Right It‚Äù, is re-teaching me this principle. Data beats opinions, he says. In another book I‚Äôm reading, ‚ÄúTrustworthy Online Controlled Experiments‚Äù, the former CEO of Netscape is quoted saying,

If we have data, let‚Äôs go with data. If all we have are opinions, let‚Äôs go with mine. - Jim Barksdale

Data sourced from your manager, your stakeholder, or your customer are invaluable to help you know if you‚Äôre solving their problem. Too often it‚Äôs easy to get stuck in the original solution that comes to our mind.
Data from customers directly shape the product. Data sourced at scale from online experiments refine it.
Opinions from the customer shape the product. Their behavior (captured as data) speaks louder than their words. Frequently, it‚Äôs challenging to correlate the two. We‚Äôre left to guess why someone actually clicked, bought, churned. It‚Äôs a beautiful cycle.

title: Buying a used car the data science way: Part 2
text:
[Update 2021-11-16] This analysis was originally written on my old blog here. You can find the source code for it here.
This is part 2 out of a two-part series on scraping used car data. Check out part 1 to learn how to scrape the data.
_________________________  For coaching on data analytics or machine learning, reach out.

title: Buying a used car the data science way: Part 2
text:
You‚Äôre in the market
So you want to buy a car, but you don‚Äôt know anything about them? Welcome to my life.
You show up at the dealer and there‚Äôs a sticker on the window. You know the difference between make and model, but you soon learn what a trim is. Some versions come with leather. Some have a sun roof. Some have all wheel drive. Some have 20k in miles, and a similarly priced car in a higher trim is at 40k miles. How do you know what you‚Äôre really paying for, and what these features are worth? And how do you know what it‚Äôll be worth when it‚Äôs four years older and has an additional 40k miles?
Pretty advanced questions for someone who just learned what a powertrain is.
In this analysis, I‚Äôll dive into how you can use data to learn a lot about an industry in a short amount of time. I‚Äôll first dive into knowing what you‚Äôre buying (now and later). Then, I‚Äôll dive into how Truecar and others might be finding their ‚Äòdeals‚Äô.

title: Buying a used car the data science way: Part 2
text:
What am I paying for?
To do any analysis, you need data. Please see my most recent post if you‚Äôre interested in learning how I got the data for this analysis. Suffice it to say, I webscraped it. The data is not my own, but belongs to Truecar.
I love using linear regression to understand my data on a granular level. In my data set, I was able to extract the make, model, year, mileage, trim, and a flag for whether the car was all wheel drive (awd == 1) or not. Putting this data into a linear regression, we can see some interesting results. First let‚Äôs look at the data we have:

library(dplyr)
load('../../data/used-car/tc-ford-edge.Rda')
# Get the prices into the appropriate scale and remove some extraneous
df$price = df$price*1000
df %>% select(-stats, -url, -int, -vin, -v6, -trueprice, -resid) %>% head()

##   price year mileage trim awd        location                   ext deal
## 1 16000 2014  28.477   SE   1    Sterling, VA                  <NA> 6514
## 2 13300 2013  64.315   SE   0   Chantilly, VA                  <NA> 1784
## 3 13800 2013  72.111  SEL   0     Fairfax, VA Mineral Gray Metallic 3331
## 4 16000 2014  27.490   SE   0    Manassas, VA          Oxford White 5448
## 5 12000 2013  66.825   SE   0 Clarksville, MD Mineral Gray Metallic   NA
## 6 14900 2014  65.157   SE   0    Manassas, VA Tuxedo Black Metallic 4436
##    mpyr
## 1  7.12
## 2 12.86
## 3 14.42
## 4  6.87
## 5 13.37
## 6 16.29
Now let‚Äôs see the regression results.

mod <- lm(price ~ as.factor(year) + mileage + trim + awd, data = df)
summary(mod)

## 
## Call:
## lm(formula = price ~ as.factor(year) + mileage + trim + awd, 
##     data = df)
## 
## Residuals:
##     Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max 
## -4755.7  -854.6    -2.7   877.5  5024.2 
## 
## Coefficients:
##                      Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
## (Intercept)         22216.400    788.885  28.162  < 2e-16 ***
## as.factor(year)2013  1267.037    625.804   2.025   0.0442 *  
## as.factor(year)2014  3160.017    645.152   4.898 1.92e-06 ***
## as.factor(year)2015  5664.470    710.322   7.975 9.56e-14 ***
## as.factor(year)2016  6166.658    821.469   7.507 1.68e-12 ***
## as.factor(year)2017  9082.971    878.956  10.334  < 2e-16 ***
